description: (1570s) From snap +â€Ž dragon, from children pretending that the flower is a dragon that opens its "mouth" when squeezed on the sides. For the parlour game sense, the 1704 Swift quotation is apparently the earliest appearance in print.

entries.meaning: (countable) Any plant of the genus Antirrhinum, with showy yellow, white or red flowers.
examples: Snapdragon leaves are asymmetrical with respect to dorsal-ventral surfaces (Fig. 6.6A).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A game in which raisins are snatched from a vessel containing burning brandy, and eaten; the substance snatched and eaten during the playing of the game; the vessel used for the game.
examples: "Exactly as you predicted, Mr. Graham," said Madeline; "blind-man's buff at a quarter past three, and snap-dragon at five."
